text:
My friend and I travelled to Colombo in January from the UK. The hotel is large, modern, well appointed. Comfortable bedrooms, ample choice at breakfast (which can get busy). Our room had a Lakeside view, pretty enough, but it also overlooked the poolside bar/club which had loud music playing till the very early hours, rendering sleep a challenge. I would recommend checking this, before you book, or stay on the other side of the hotel.

However, what soured our stay was that the day after we checked in at the hotel, we were victims of a scam.

As we left the hotel to walk to the local temple in the morning (still jet lagged), a man claiming to be a hotel employee started a conversation with us. He claimed his name was Sangha Perera. He appeared to be helpful, giving us directions. As it was raining, he advised us that taking a tuk tuk around the main tourist attractions would be easier and cheaper. As he was connected to the hotel, we trusted him. He 'found' us a tuktuk, and even joined us acting as an unnoficial guide. Eventually he ended up taking us to an 'officially credited' government approved jewellery shop, which had 50% off,  he even told us a percentage of profits would be donated to tsunami orphans. We were pressurised by the shop management (all men) into purchasing items.  After that the tuktuk driver told us the ride for 2.5 hours would cost equivalent of £100 in rupees, and things got very heated until we paid up.

We reported the matter to the Jeevani Perera, Lobby Manager at Colombo Cinnamon Lakeside hotel. She told us the man did not work at the hotel, and an identical incident had happened previously. We also spoke to the hotel security officer, who said he would check hotel security videos. Later we even sent them photos of the man claiming to be an hotel employee and the tuktuk driver. We were disappointed to receive no response from them.

BE WARNED if you stay at this hotel. Scammers are working around there, and the hotel seemingly turns a blind eye, without advising guests checking in! (SEE PHOTOS OF SCAMMERS ATTACHED). Am sure the same thing goes on outside other hotels too...

We eventually went to the local police, who were helpful, and they went with us to get our money back from the jewellery shop (Lanka Sapphire Lapidary PVT Ltd., no 83 Dharmaphala Mawatha, Colombo 07), but it was not easy to do so. A salutary lesson.
title: BEWARE : SCAMMERS  OPERATING !

text:
This hotel styles itself as a quiet oasis in busy Colombo, and the heritage building itself is beautifully ornate, belonging to the former Sri Lankan royal family. The central courtyard is calm and pretty, but it’s exposed to the noise of the outside - unfortunately on my arrival a loud Christmas party was being thrown by the neighbours.

Rooms are cosy and decorated well if a little tired looking in places, and the toilet and shower are outside at the back, in a secluded spot. Just be aware! You don’t share with other guests but it’s not totally private. The rooms also let in a lot of noise from outside as they’re not totally cocooned away from the courtyard. 

The breakfast had a lot of choice, and was all delicious but was a little late in terms of timeliness. There were only two rooms occupied so I imagine if it was busier it would be more chaotic. There’s also no soya milk available so not perfect for us lactose intolerant guests. The hotel also doesn’t have a liquor licence.

Staff are nice and chatty and overall It was a nice one night stay in Colombo but any more than this and it might have been a little less comfortable.

text:
We arrived at this hotel as part of a company retreat. Our party occupied 5 suites and consisted of 10 people.

This is a lovely property that is not too far away from the Imaduwa exit. The road leading from the turnoff point to the hotel is somewhat narrow but decent.

Hotel grounds and garden: The hotel sits on a 12 acre tea estate which is carefully landscaped to allow for a more authentic natural setting. 

The architecture and layout of the hotel has been beautifully planned out so that guests are immersed in the natural environs, albeit probably a little too immersed during sudden monsoonal showers!. The Koggala lake can be glimpsed through the trees from certain places but there really is no satisfactory view of it from any part of the hotel.

Since this is on the top of a hill, the grounds slope up and down towards the rooms which are at different levels, with jagged stone steps leading to them; not quite elderly friendly. 

Some paths were rather poorly lit at night as some of the garden lights were either not switched on, or malfunctioning.

Room: My husband and I stayed in the Araliya suite which is on the northern side of the property and has mainly a jungle/tea estate view.

Positives - the room is quite spacious and the decor is quite interesting with antique chests, brass bells and carved candlesticks which gave the room character. The bed was comfortable and big and my favourite was the bookcase filled with a variety of interesting books!

Negatives - My first concern was when I noticed a long line of black ants in the bathroom which I pointed out and they were cleared immediately. Unfortunately I later noticed more black ants emerging from a picture frame in the toilet and discovered a massive colony inhabiting the otherwise charming and well-stocked bookcase. I never quite recovered from this bad impression. 
In addition the shower had no door which meant the whole bathroom got wet. The mat next to the bathroom sink was also quite old and dirty. The walk-in closet was dusty with cobwebs on the clothes-hangers. The room smelt musty, and overall, felt like it had been hastily put together for us; this did not reflect well on their housekeeping standards. They did get rid of the ants after I complained, so that was good. 

Food: lunch was Sri Lankan style and offered as a buffet as our party consisted of 10 people. The food was very good although somewhat lacking in spice. The cocktails were overall good. My favourite meal was dinner, where my barramundi was cooked to perfection. Breakfast was pretty good too. No complaints there!

The service: the staff consists of some very lovely and friendly people - Malsha, Henry, and Amila, who seem eager to please, but unfortunately lack training and proper oversight ensuring smooth operations. The wonderful staff are let down by not having sufficient guidance from the management, which is such a pity. 

The manager of operations did pay us a visit during dinner to enquire about our experience. After I mentioned the ants and musty smell he offered a bottle of wine and skedaddled before I could bring up the other issues. 
We later approached him, sat him down and had a cordial discussion of some of the issues which he listened to patiently and on the whole took the criticism rather well.

Overall, this is a great hotel in a lovely location which is let down by deficient management and poor maintenance. This is such a pity, as it is obvious that a great deal of care and attention to detail has gone into the design of this place. I am personally disappointed that such a lovely and unique property doesn’t have the service and maintenance it deserves.

text:
I stayed at KK (as its affectionately known) for two nights in April last year. My partner and I were the only guests at the property. 

Although with sporadic hot water (and strangely two shower heads which couldn't be used at the same time), the room was superb- spacious and overlooking the tea plantations, with several lounges to laze on throughout the day, and if you keep all the shutters open at night, wake to the sounds of birds in the morning. The grounds are well cared for and there is a gorgeous big pool for cooling off during the day. The big highlight, however, was the deliciously soft sheets- which I also slept under at the Galle Fort Hotel- who pinched whose idea?

My qualm was with the service, and more importantly- the food.

Despite being the only guests in the property, we literally had to track down any staff for food or drinks requests (they were usually found drinking tea and gossiping in the kitchen). Then, only a few of them were competent enough with English and hospitality skills to come through with the goods. However, those star staff who did manage to pull a few hours while we were there were fantastic.

The food is however, very hit and miss. One day we had a superb lunch of tomato soup with salad and fresh foccacia bread, the bread still warm from the oven, the soup perfectly spiced and loaded with fresh herbs. But the concoction labeled a Thai red curry for dinner was simply inedible. I lived in Thailand for several years and while I have had some very dubious "Thai food" around the world, this one took the cake. I'm sure an entire bottle of fish sauce had been emptied onto the prawns, which must have died gagging from the stench. To add salt to the wound, we were told that the "chef" had been specially sent to Chiang Mai to "learn how to cook Thai food". And, when I finally tracked down a staff member and tell them eating this curry was like sticking your nose in a bubbling broth of  pla-daek, the chef came out and glared at us as if he was the one whose sensibilities had been offended!  We weren't offered a replacement and hence ended up sharing one meal and going to bed mildly hungry.... The waiter was sympathetic though- maybe he had tried the curry too!

And finally, a question- if we are staying on a tea plantation in one of the biggest tea producing nations on earth, why are we made to drink Liptons?
title: beautiful setting- pitty about the food

text:
First off, we came to Sri Lanka for a quick R&R break. We wanted a beautiful property to relax, read a book, spend time together, eat good food, and recharge.

The property itself is indeed beautiful—newly refurbished and tastefully done. Surrounded by tea gardens and tall Eucalyptus trees, the ambiance is tranquil, with birds chirping throughout the day. With only us as guests for 2 out of our 3 nights, it was a very peaceful property.

The food was generally good in terms of taste.

So, why were we not happy with our stay and wished we had chosen a different property?

The issue was with the service and our experience with the staff.

We usually find SEA hospitality to be amazing, but the service here was neither polished nor warm and welcoming. On the night we arrived, around 11:30 PM, the staff were available to welcome us and serve hot meals, which was appreciated. But from there, things went downhill.

Despite the property advertising that breakfast, lunch, dinner, and high tea were included in the package, we encountered several issues. For breakfast, we were told we could only select one option. If we wanted both scrambled eggs and waffles, we had to pay extra - no problem, but usually when you say meals are covered, you don't put such limitations. Right after Stafford Bungalow we stayed at another 5-star beach property which also came with a full package and there, the chef and staff went above and beyond and even made us meals which were not on the menu! 

For lunch, we ordered Sri Lankan rice and curry, but were told it wasn't available without ample notice—notice that wasn't mentioned the night before or at breakfast. High tea, advertised on their website and social media, was just a slice of sponge cake and tea. When questioned, they said the full high tea was paid, but they hadn’t asked if we wanted it. The chef later offered complimentary high tea for the next day but repeatedly asked us to have a light lunch to avoid too much food - making us feel like we were eating too much. 

My impression is that they thought they'd get away with a low-effort high-tea. When they saw that we complained, they lied saying it was paid. And later to cover it, the chef said we will offer it as a complimentary service to us. 

Cheese platters advertised online were another issue. When requested, the butler seemed confused, eventually serving basic cheese more suitable for a sandwich.

During checkout, we were repeatedly asked to return an adapter we had left in the room. Despite informing them where it was, they couldn't find it until we personally pointed it out. It made us feel like they thought we were stealing it and taking it with us. 

Overall, we felt hesitant to order food, worried if it was available or if we'd be made to feel like we were eating a lot. Whether due to laziness since we were the only guests or a possible racist undertone—favoring Western guests over us Asians—the service left much to be desired.

It's a shame that such a beautiful property left us with a sour taste. Perhaps others, especially from Europe or the USA, might receive better service, but we did not have the positive experience we hoped for.
title: Beautiful property, but the staff and service left us wanting! Won't come again!

text:
We stayed at the Stafford Bungalows for two nights on our recent trip to Sri Lanka. While this property generally gets very good reviews, I think we were unlucky on two accounts. Firstly the weather; it was pouring for most of the time we were there. We did however managed to have one high tea on the lawn, which was lovely. 
Secondly, and much more importantly,  the manager was not at the property during most of our stay.  This meant we encountered a number of hiccups, which may not necessarily be the norm. Our driver had not been to the property before and had trouble getting directions from the staff.  The staff did not speak much English so when we arrived we did not get a proper over view of the property. There was no internet during our stay so when we tried to download the property web site (to get our own information) this was also impossible. The staff’s lack of English meant that breakfast orders were mixed up and other requests were confused. The dinner for the two nights we were there was exactly the same- a choice of Sri Lanka or chicken dinner.

We stayed in the generously sized front room, which actually has a private terrace over looking the garden. The room was suppose to be a double room but it was actually two single beds pushed together.  The beds were not the same height as the mattresses were of different thicknesses. The rainy weather meant the room was quite damp. I tried to be “green” and not ask for the towels to be changed after one use but this was a mistake as the towels did not dry all day. 

The manager arrived back during our stay, but we were disappointed when one couple, who asked, were given a tour of the property but no one else was invited to join in.

While this review may sound a bit harsh the price of the bungalows is not cheap so one tends to expect top-notch service. The property is lovely and with a little more attention to detail from staff and management this property could take its rightful place among many of the other period bungalows which offer accommodation in tea country. Please at least print off the hotel web site information and leave it in a folder in the room. Please make sure some one with good English is resident at all times.
title: Beautiful place but be sure to visit when the manager is in

text:
I’m clearly in the minority here as Niyagama has got splendid feedback from most of its visitors. Just to put this review in context, there are some aspects of the hotel that are just not suited to my tastes and requirements (no fault of the hotel though). 

So here are the things you need to know before booking Niyagama: it’s 20 mins plus to Galle and there are no restaurants and shops in the vicinity, there is no TV in the room nor a kettle to make coffee or tea, no room service and alcohol is not served in the premises. Children below 12 aren’t allowed in (the silence is one of the highlights of the property). 

The positives during my stay were that I was offered an upgrade and a late check out, which was very nice of them. 

But here is where I began to have conflicted feelings about this place. The hotel arranges tuk tuk transfers into Galle and I was told this was cheaper than taking one myself. Turned out it was not. Airport transfers are cheaper by half if you book from a taxi device yourself. A mosquito repellant with a sticker price of SLR 250 was charged to me at SLR 300! Really? Is that SLR 50 really more important than the perception this creates amongst guests? My other issues were with the food (fine per se but begins to get boring on the third day and the closest restaurants are all in Galle) and the patchy wifi in the rooms. The hotel says wifi is available in public areas so I guess this is expected. 

Lastly, and this really hurt, I was charged a ridiculously low exchange rate by their Manager when exchanging dollars even though the hotel used a higher rate when converting the price of my massage from USD to SLR. Nor was I given a receipt. I was told this is an additional “service” and therefore the rates were lower. Next time, please inform guests of the exchange rate before completing the transaction. 

In all, I was expecting great things from Niyagama but unfortunately my experience came up short.

text:
We finished our honeymoon at The Fortress Resort and Spa.  The hotel itself is nice and very clean but overall we found it to be underwhelming.

Staff were not the most professional or welcoming. Reception were aloof, waiting staff inexperienced or untrained (we had six different employees ask us the same question during dinner in a space of a few minutes) and a chef was on his mobile phone wandering around the tables during dinner service.  We felt this was due to a lack of management presence as we did not once see anyone clearly in charge.

We were hoping to see strong Sri Lankan influences but it felt as if the vibrant culture of the country had been muted to suit a more contemporary feel. The interior of the hotel could have been anywhere.

The rooms were generously sized and cleanliness faultless. The bathroom in particular was spotless and had everything one could need. Laundry service excellent however there was no need for garments to be returned in plastic packaging.

The position of this hotel is good in that it is right on the Ocean. However the sea is rough and you would need to walk down the beach before attempting a swim. There is an attractive pool plus sun loungers on the lawns.
We had a ground floor room with doors out to a small seating area and then directly on to the lawn; you can lie in bed and see the sea. Bed was big and comfortable and the room was bigger than most. There was an excellent shower and freestanding bath as well as two sinks, so a good bathroom.
We only stayed three nights and ate only once in the seafood restaurant; food was ok but service was somewhat hot and miss.
Breakfast is fine without being great. 
We ate in Galle where there are many restaurants and a degree of “life”.
Indeed the biggest downside of the hotel is that it is so far out of Galle; at least half an hour. We had been in Sri Lanka for some time and Galle is the only town we have found in which we would wish to spend some time.
There is also an issue with the Tuk Tuk drivers who seem to represent the local “mafia” and grossly overcharge (3500Rupees for a return trip to Galle, 800 Rupees to the local pharmacy). Indeed, when we asked the hotel to arrange a car to Colombo, they did it through the Tuk Tuk gang. Shops and taxi drivers have to pay commission to these people as well. They represent a significant negative and the hotel needs to resolve this problem - perhaps a hotel mini bus shuttle going to Galle and back would be a good start.
In conclusion, if I was tired out and wanted a week by the pool, this would be fine. If I wanted to take advantage of Galle, I would find a hotel there. As such my score is based upon an average of Hotel being good and location being poor.

text:
The hotel is beautiful, the rooms are large, the pool is massive and really stunning with a view over the sea but it's not really a luxury hotel in any other respect. 
There are issues with shabbiness of the external and internal areas of the building and deck area around the pool, the place could do with some refurbishment. There are a lot of crows/other birds that make a lot of mess around the garden and pool area that isn't cleaned up adequately, some of the sunbeds had bird poo on them and the grass is filthy. 
The service is great as you enter the hotel and poolside service is very good, the staff are all very friendly and do their best to be helpful. 

The breakfast is very good, with a large selection and good bread, something hard to find in Sri Lanka. 

Food wise however, breakfast is definitely the better offering than the options later in the day.  For the price you pay and the supposed 5 star rating, i've had far better service and food in a £10 a night backpacker hostel in India. 
My girlfriend and I are vegan, which can cause some problems when travelling but you expect this not to be the case in a Luxury hotel. Unfortunately on the first night we had some issues with our meal as although they had altered some of the vegetarian options for us to make them vegan, they had done so with no creativity or thought as to the flavour. This may have been partly due to a communication problem with the staff or lack of skill on the chefs part but it didn't seem like they had had any training for this sort of request. I'd hate to see how they handle the request of somebody with a serious allergy. 

When one of the service managers came over to apologise it didn't really seem like he was listening so we were surprised when they took the meals we had had a problem with off the bill. (Something you would have been offered immediately in any bog standard UK restaurant if you were unhappy with the food.)

The restaurant definitely needs to get with the times and up their game with regards to these kind of requests. We had thought about going for the Fine Dining experience but after the first night we really didn't have confidence in the quality of the chefs to pay that much for a meal here.  
Instead we went for the 'safe option' of Sri Lankan rice and curry for the second night, which despite being vegan and edible really wasn't as good as you'd expect from a 5 star hotel. As a comparison, we ate in one of the restaurants (Nuga Gama) at Cinnamon Grand in Colombo a few days before and the food was of a much higher standard there. 

Although I can only personally comment on the options available to vegans, my mother had some of the other fish/seafood options and said they were't up to the standard she'd expect either.

If you're not too fussed about food and happy with a beautiful pool and good rooms then maybe it would be worth the 5 stars to you but I honestly don't think its quite there.

text:
We booked a Loft Suite for 2 nights. The suite has a very spacious downstairs area, including an indoor plunge pool and a half bathroom. Upstairs is pretty much the same format as their standard rooms (we had other family members booked into these), except that the staircase cuts into the bathroom area, resulting in a bathroom not as spacious as the standard room version (notable missing items were a jacuzzi bathtub and a second washbasin). The layout of the suite was a bit odd, for example having an entrance on each floor meant having to put up 2 do not disturb signs every time. There was bizarrely just one phone (upstairs). The result being we ended doing a lot more stair climbing than planned! The property is fairly dated and certain aspects of the rooms are due for a refurb. For example, our balcony door was almost falling off its hinges...

The resort has a reasonably large pool and plenty of loungers. The beach is a few feet below but is very rocky. They had roped out what was a really small area where you could actually enter the water. The beach setup wasn't a surprise though, as rocky/inaccessible beaches are a pretty common feature around resorts in Sri Lanka.

There are 3 restaurants in the hotel. The main one serves all 3 meals and includes buffet breakfast and dinners. Then there was a casual seafood restaurant (not sure if this was open at the time) and a fine dining venue which has a set menu every night (priced at around Rs 15k). We stayed on a full board basis, and one positive was how generous they were with the inclusions. While the fine dining option incurred a surcharge, in the main restaurant we were able to order anything from the extensive menu under our package. This included things like lobster and imported steak - and all this available for lunch and for dinner as well (we could combine the buffet and a la carte options). Drinks prices were reasonable, with cocktails priced at around Rs 1,000 (£5). The quality of the food varied, but was generally decent. The dinner buffet selection was perhaps lacking in variety however (although they did have different themed nights). Desserts were disappointing as well - which was ironic, this being the place that sells the world's most expensive dessert!

Service was a weak point. We endured extensive delays for orders during some meals, and occasionally incorrect items were delivered as well. Our suite came with an assigned butler, but this was effectively a gimmick, as our butler was actually a waiter in the main restaurant, and apart from during our meals was generally nowhere to be seen (with no specific way of contacting him provided either). To their credit, after a major complaint was filed during one lunch, they really stepped up their game for our final dinner, where we had our butler and another waiter attending to our every need. Shame we had to complain to get there though.

Overall, this is a reasonable luxury property, but it has definitely seen better days, and I feel it no longer lives up to its billing as one of the finest beach resorts on the island. Although we enjoyed discounted local rates, at the full tourist rates this place would be overpriced, especially relative to some other resorts around Sri Lanka. There are no shortage of higher end beach resorts on this part of the island (many of which are newly opened), and I would definitely be trying out a few others before considering a return to The Fortress.

I don’t typically write reviews, but I felt compelled to share my experience at Cinnamon Hotel in Yala, as it was extremely disappointing and felt more like a tourist trap than a relaxing getaway.

Over four hours, we saw only two elephants, a few birds, and some water buffalo. The much-hyped leopard sightings were non-existent, likely due to the loud noise, fumes, and the sheer number of vehicles swarming the area. It was disheartening to see the animals surrounded by such disruption, which directly contradicts the park’s claims of caring for wildlife. Additionally, many jeeps were carrying only one or two passengers, raising concerns about environmental sustainability. Litter and plastic waste throughout the park only added to our disappointment.

The hotel itself felt tired and poorly maintained. Our room had broken lights—so bad that I had to remove the bulbs myself in order to sleep. The atmosphere throughout the resort was more like a children’s club than a relaxing retreat. Children were running freely in all areas, including the main bar, which played loud music and showed cricket on a large screen. Even the quieter bar was filled with noise from children and shouting parents, leaving little room for a peaceful evening. When we suggested playing more relaxing music to help with the atmosphere, the staff simply said they couldn’t change it.

The buffet was average at best, and the pool area was loud and chaotic, again dominated by noisy families, with little consideration for other guests seeking rest or relaxation. Staff did not seem trained or empowered to manage the environment in a way that balanced family fun with the needs of other travelers.

The property is in a prime location with a small lake on one side and also beach access and proximity to the park entrance. It has been sensitively constructed to blend in within the jungle/  nature reserve surroundings and the individual chalets are very comfortable, nicely appointed with wooden furnishings, decent bathroom etc. the staff are all exemplary - friendly, eager to please and knowledgable and we stayed over New Year’s Eve when all the staff participated in the dinner and party including creating dance routines for the guests. Great sense of camaraderie.

On a slight negative note the  facilities are starting to look and feel a bit dated and certainly not worth to the extortionate prices they were charging over the Christmas and New Year period. These would be 5 star in London or the best resorts in Asia and certainly not value for money for a 4 star resort like Cinnamon Wild.

More seriously for most guests the main draw of visiting this resort (and what you are paying a lot of money for) is the safari experience but even that is now being rapidly spoiled. There seems to be no regulation on the number of jeeps or visitors in the park so it is overrun with noisy 4x4s (over 200 apparently) on the morning we were there - all raising to find a sighting of a leopard or elephant. Hence not surprising minimal chance of seeing anything under those conditions. I would certainly not visit again during the peak December to Feb period.

Seems like the safari operators are a law unto themselves and with the amount of money changing hands - US$40 per entry PER foreign tourists and another US$40 -100 per vehicle it certainly isn’t good value especially if you have experienced safaris in other parts of the world. In fact there was more wildlife in and around the resort itself including crocodiles in the lake, peacocks and monkeys strolling the grounds and even an elephant wandering around while we were there. I would certainly think twice about doing the safari again and probably only during the dry season - April to July. I know many other tourists we spoke to also had a disappointing safari experience. 

Finally although it has been one of longest wettest rainy seasons in Sri Lanka I was surprised how bad the road leading up to the 4 main 4/5 star resorts was and how I’ll prepared they were for receiving guests including arranging proper SUVs to ferry guest from the points normal cars couldn’t get past. All seemed a bit disorganised and the road leading to the resorts just incredibly poor. Hard to understand why the hotels have invested in this given how much they are charging tho I think the Hilton has paved just the section leading to its property:
title: Charming if slightly dated resort lifted by the great staff; think hard about visiting if just for the safari experience

We booked a jungle chalet that was advertised with pictures and wording that said it had a private balcony.  We were taken to a tiny adjoined room with shared balcony which unfortunately had a very loud Indian family staying next door, who were part of a group and they were yelling to each other from each of their balconies.  So we asked to be moved, and requested a room like the pictures with its own private balcony.  They absolutely understood the situation and rectified it immediately.  A great job, but tbh,  we were moved to the room that we booked and paid for.  So no real favours, but they did it well. 
We booked a safari with them for the next day, easily done. Then told an hour later that the national park, zone 1, which is right next door to them was closed for 3 days due to being too wet to take vehicles.  It was going to be repaired.  So to go on a safari we had to drive 1.5 hours to zone 5. Well, we are all there for a reason....so we reluctantly agreed. It was a bloody long day and that was the half day tour. On our return we are told if we want to do another half day zone 1 is open again...wtf. thought it was closed for 3 day?? We declined but the worst part was, I went to the restaurant later that afternoon to get some drinks and the same guide was telling another family that zone 1 was closed due to bad weather and they had to go 1.5 hours to zone 5. Wtaf. There is something dodgy going on here and I can't say it's just that hotel, I think the safari operators run this town and there is something that just doesn't feel right. But, we did the tour, we saw elephants water buffalo peacocks etc etc so the tour ticked the boxes. 
The food in the a la carte restaurant is shocking, but the buffet is outstanding. 
The floors inside and outside the rooms are incredibly slippery, scarily so. But the rooms are quite clean and well equipped. 
So you see, it was good, but it was bad.....so it gets 3 stars from us.
title: A strange stay...

text:
This hotel is a short drive from Dambulla, where there truly isn't much to see (other than the Golden Buddha and the Cave Temple). It is however a decent base for nearby towns and sights (Sigiriya approx 30 min drive, Polonnaruwa about 1,5 hours). The hotel can be found at the end of a poorly maintained dirt track, but it's in beautiful surroundings with the small lake leading to lots of wildlife, especially birds. The rooms are a good size, clean and generally well kept. Beds are a nice size and are very comfortable. The staff are very attentive and seem to want to do their best for their guests. 

The negative side of it being so isolated is (for example) that the hotel can charge high prices at their two restaurants. There's nothing else close enough to choose from. A dinner for two (1 starter, 2 main course, 1 beer and 1 glass of wine) at their restaurants will cost you between 6000-9000 rupees. You don't have much choice either, as there isn't much else on offer in Dambulla which is a 15 minute drive away. 

They also offer (very) inflated transport prices. I had a chat with one of the managers about this whilst I was there, and he seemed to understand my feedback. We found a great local driver online and he was about half the price of what the hotel were asking for a Polonnaruwa and safari day trip. Feel free to send me a message if you want his details. 

We experienced several power cuts during our stay. If you have a room over the restaurant, be aware that you will be affected by noise/loud music until approx 10:30pm. Not ideal if you have children or have a particularly early start. They were kind enough to end the music a little bit earlier once they understood that we were getting up at 4am.

Lots of positives, a few negatives. All in all an average stay for the price that we paid. A nice bit of luxury for a night or two if that's what you're looking for.
title: Isolated (for better and for worse)

We were very disappointed with our trip to Jetwing Lake. What started as a very positive experience quickly turned negative. 

Firstly, the hotel itself is lovely, our room was fabulous with great views, and the pool area was great. On arrival we enjoyed a delicious a la carte meal in the restaurant with great service.

The next day we went to see some sites before resting by the pool in the afternoon. Come 4pm, a large number of Sri Lanka locals checked in. This would not have been a problem, but the hotel atmosphere completely changed. Gone was our relaxing, 5-star experience that we had paid a lot of money for. 

Around 25 people came to the pool, shouting and making lots of noise. The babies were in the pool without nappies, which made us not want to use it! People were stood at the end of our sunbeds taking photos and selfies which made us feel very uncomfortable (I don’t particularly want to be in peoples photos in my bikini!!). In the end we gave up and went up to the room. 

In the evening on arrival at the restaurant, gone was the relaxed, intimate atmosphere of the night previous. This was replaced by large groups of locals and an awful singer opting for the Enrique Iglesias classics! We were shown to our table and told ‘it’s a buffet’ before the lady walked off. text:
The Riff is clearly *trying* to be a 5* destination hotel, but apart from the price, it’s just not there. Having come here for a night on our way to Colombo from the Anantara in Tangalle, it was obvious that the owners here have spent some time at the Anantara and tried to mimic certain elements of the resort - from the water bottles to the exact same toiletries - however the lack of experience shows when it comes to the all-important small touches, which are ultimately what makes a hotel stand out.

To highlight a few pro’s and con’s;
- We were the only room not occupied by part of a large Russian group who completely took over the hotel - from the sun loungers, to the pool, to even having Russian music playing at breakfast, which we found very intimidating and created an uncomfortable atmosphere. Had we been contacted by the hotel in advance and pre-warned about the large group we would have sought to stay elsewhere.
- There’s no shower or bathroom by the pool, which means you have no choice but to traipse sand through the pool, hotel and your room.
- Overall cleanliness was not up to scratch (as per my pictures). I would expect a hotel of this age and rating to be spotless.
- There are flies EVERYWHERE - it actually made sitting by the pool impossible. We didn’t experience this anywhere else in Sri Lanka.
- We had an adjoining room, which meant we could hear every sound from our extremely noisy neighbours. 
- The toilet situation is a classic case of style over substance - I don’t believe that anyone, no matter how close you may be, wants to see anyone else on the toilet!
- Also oddly the light switches in the bathroom didn’t work unless the main light in the bedroom was on - which clearly caused some issues in the night.
- They don’t provide any driver accommodation - again, all hotels charging these rates in Sri Lanka should (and had done up until this point).
- As far as the positives go, the staff were very prompt and friendly, it was clear they were trying very hard to please.
- Our room also had a fantastic view (although Hikkaduwa beach itself was probably our least favourite of our trip).
- The complimentary (glass) water bottles were a nice touch and contribution to avoiding plastic in the resort.

Overall I would say that the hotel has the looks but lacks the substance or depth to make it a luxury experience, and therefore we wouldn’t chose to stay again.
title: Disappointing Riff

Am 7. Januar, Ihrem letzten Abend, sind Sie nach einer Nacht mit dem Tuk Tuk gegen 23 Uhr in die Villa zurückgekehrt. Alle anderen Gäste und unsere Mitarbeiter befanden sich in ihren Zimmern. Unser 24-Stunden-Sicherheitsteam (ausgelagert an eine Sicherheitsfirma) rief unseren Senior Villa Manager George an und teilte ihm mit, dass ein Problem vorliegt, das seine Aufmerksamkeit erfordert. Er kam sofort herbei, um unsere Sicherheitsleute, Ihren Tuk-Tuk-Fahrer und Sie selbst zu finden. Sie teilten ihm mit, dass Sie wollten, dass der Fahrer zu Ihrem Zimmer kommt, und er teilte Ihnen mit, dass es sich bei uns um eine reine Anwohnervilla handelt und Gäste angemeldet werden müssen. Ihr Tuk-Tuk-Fahrer teilte George mit, dass er Ihr Ehemann und Vater Ihres Kindes sei. Da es offensichtlich war, dass unser Team dieser Lüge nicht glaubte, sagten Sie, er sei Ihr Reisebüro. George teilte Ihnen mit, dass Sie gerne im Wohn- und Essbereich (unserer Lounge) sprechen könnten, wir konnten ihm jedoch nicht erlauben, nach oben zu gehen. Er erklärte, dass wir eine strikte Richtlinie nur für Anwohner haben (die auf unserer Website deutlich gemacht wird) und dass dies auch der Sicherheit und Privatsphäre aller Gäste, einschließlich Ihnen und Ihrem Kind, dient.
Dies war für Ihren Fahrer nicht akzeptabel. Er wurde gegenüber unserem gesamten Team aggressiv und versuchte, George mit der Drohung einer schlechten Bewertung zu erpressen. Dies wurde zusätzlich zu George von unserem unabhängigen Sicherheitsteam bestätigt. Unser Sicherheitsteam hat in seinem Bericht auch angegeben, dass es sich bei der Person um einen Tuk-Tuk-Fahrer handelt, der für ein Hotel in der Nähe arbeitet. Das Hotel hat dies bestätigt.
Villa Sielen Diva ist eine familiengeführte Villa und wird seit 2018 betrieben. Wir hatten das Glück, an vielen schönen Momenten im Leben unserer Gäste teilzuhaben, von Geburtstagen, Heiratsanträgen, Jubiläen, Hochzeiten und Familientreffen. Unsere Gäste haben das Recht, die von ihnen gewählten Entscheidungen zu treffen. Wir respektieren dies, jedoch nicht die potenziellen Risiken für die Sicherheit unserer anderen Gäste und Mitarbeiter. In der Vergangenheit haben sich ausschließlich weibliche Reisende für unsere Villa entschieden, gerade wegen unserer hohen Ansprüche an die Sicherheit unserer Gäste. Wie die Leser dieser Rezension zu schätzen wissen, können Hotels (insbesondere kleine Hotels) der Bedrohung durch schlechte Bewertungen ausgesetzt sein, wir werden jedoch bei unseren Sicherheitsstandards keine Kompromisse eingehen.

Berücksichtigen Sie Ihre Kommentare in Ihrer Rezension. Cappuccino ist verfügbar und unseren Aufzeichnungen zufolge haben Sie ihn beim Frühstück mit Kokosmilch getrunken. Sollten Sie noch mehr Salz und Pfeffer gewünscht haben, konnten Sie gerne einen der Butler fragen. Wir wären Ihnen dankbar, wenn Sie erfahren würden, welche Zutaten in Ihrem Avocado-Toast gefehlt haben, da es sich um eine standardmäßige und beliebte Bestellung handelt, die unsere Köche täglich zubereiten. Unsere Köche befolgen ein festgelegtes Rezept. Teilen Sie uns daher bitte mit, was gefehlt hat. Wir servieren unsere pochierten Eier mit flüssigem Eigelb. Sollten Sie jedoch ein festeres Eigelb gewünscht haben, können Sie dies gerne dem Butler mitteilen, und unsere Köche hätten dann eine neue Bestellung vorbereitet. Es ist schade, dass Sie während Ihres 4-tägigen Aufenthalts bei uns keinem unserer Teammitglieder darüber informiert haben. Täglich werden den Gästen frische Handtücher zur Verfügung gestellt. Wenn Sie Ihre Handtücher jedoch aufhängen, geht unser Reinigungsteam davon aus, dass Sie Ihr Handtuch gerne wiederverwenden möchten, wie es in Hotels weltweit üblich ist. Dies steht auch im Hinweis neben den Handtüchern. In Ihrem Schlafzimmer gibt es 2 Fenster, die geöffnet werden können. Sie sind nicht verriegelt und Sie müssen zum Öffnen lediglich den Griff nach unten drehen. Es handelt sich um einen einfachen Mechanismus, der einer Tür ähnelt. Wir verstehen nicht, warum Sie es nicht öffnen konnten, aber auch hier ist es schade, dass Sie dies während Ihres Aufenthalts nicht erwähnt haben, da unser Team Ihnen gerne gezeigt hätte, wie man die Fenster öffnet.
Frau Sandra, Sie wissen sehr wohl, dass wir keine Probleme damit hatten, dass Sie Ihren Transport selbst organisieren konnten. Die meisten unserer Gäste reisen mit ihrem Auto und Fahrer und treffen ihre Reise selbständig. Das Problem, das wir hatten, war, dass Sie Ihren Fahrer bei Ihrem letzten Aufenthalt bei uns in Ihr Schlafzimmer bringen wollten. Wir können nur davon ausgehen, dass Sie unseren Standpunkt und damit den Grund verstanden haben, warum Sie in Ihrer Bewertung nicht darauf Bezug genommen haben.
Wir wünschen Ihnen und Ihrem kleinen Jungen eine gute Reise und hoffen, dass er sich von seiner Krankheit erholt hat.
